Depending on the status of each host, ...
I would put the statement about single host physical LED design as a separate NOTE as it is very important to show this does not affect the single host environment.

The proposed design will be tested in...

"can" indicates it is optional..."will" indicates it is a requirement of implementing the design, which I think is needed here.
All my previous comments have been addressed.  I agree with Matt's comments that more info needs to be given around event handling to get to a +1 from me.
Agree with Matt's comments that more info needs to be given around event handling.

This sounds like it needs to know that udev is done with its events?  How would it know that? 

What if a card with LEDs off of an IO/LED expander is added at runtime (and there is some code that would bind the 955x or whatever driver)?

If the service that was triggered from the udev event just sent a dbus message to your new daemon, then it wouldn't need a concept of 'done'?
or is your daemon doing an inotify watch on that file so dbus always reflects what's in it, which could also handle removes?

> What if a card with LEDs off of an IO/LED expander is added at runtime (and there is some code that would bind the 955x or whatever driver)?

This design handles LEDs which are configured as GPIO pins in device tree file.


> If the service that was triggered from the udev event just sent a dbus message to your new daemon, then it wouldn't need a concept of 'done'?


yes, for that approach, I have posted in mailing list to receive suggestions.
https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2022-July/031315.html


> or is your daemon doing an inotify watch on that file so dbus always reflects what's in it, which could also handle removes?


yes, the file will be monitored using inotify to watch the changes.
The proposed design is now implemented based on EM configuration.

Hi Jayashree,

Firstly, I sincerely apologise for taking so long to get to this, especially because I've made a number of comments. Broadly I like the proposal of moving to a single daemon instance, however I'm concerned about the design direction of inotify in your proposal.
I will work on your suggestions and update the patchset ASAP.
Removed udev rules & script and added entity manager configuration to support LEDs.

This seems like an implementation detail rather than a high level design problem.

But regardless, why not use an internal DBus interface and a helper binary to poke the information in? Or better yet, entity-manager?
Removed udev rules & script and added entity manager configuration to support LEDs.
Definitely on board with this though.
We'll need to massage the grammar slightly here.
Please see the DBus and entity-manager suggestions above.
I am not in favour of this approach.
As per your suggestions, I have used entity manager configuration to support LEDs. Please provide your thoughts on this implementation.
Please don't invent top-level sections. Try to stick to the sections in the design template.
This feels redundant - you've already said all of this above. Did you have a purpose in mind for this text?
Removed the text and explained in the proposed design.
That's a statement of what's changing. It's not a statement of the impact. Have you thought about how this will affect applications making use of the LEDs? Please discuss those thoughts here.

It seems you've omitted the "Alternatives Considered" section. IMO this is not wise - you should be able to demonstrate the trade-offs of different approaches. Otherwise it appears as if you haven't given consideration to others and it's hard to have confidence that your proposed design is what we should proceed with. Consider the DBus/entity-manager suggestions above vs inotify for instance.
How? And how will these tests integrate with existing test infrastructure?

Whether this needs to be tested with automation test cases ?

Could you please clarify this statement.

Yes. How are we going to maintain the implementation without it becoming a burden? How do you test it? Manual testing doesn't scale, and with humans in the loop, tends to be error-prone.

Can it be done with unit tests alone? Or do we need some form of integration tests? If the latter, how does this impact openbmc-test-automation?
Adding the EM reviewers as it's integral to the proposal as it stands

I'd go further and say a new application is proposed. Reading below I'm concerned about the effort involved to reconcile LED support in existing systems with this new approach if we removed the existing pair of daemons.

I think this phrasing is pretty loose. What EM cares about is *specific* board designs. So I'd write this as "LEDs on a given board"

Also, I think you need to justify why EM is a requirement. It's not obvious why to me, but perhaps it falls out of your reasoning. Having said that, I'd certainly *prefer* an EM-based solution 😊
This isn't a requirement, this is an implementation detail that potentially falls out of the actual requirement that you need to manage tight coupling between distinct LEDs.

What does this mean? Does phosphor-led-sysfs even have a role in the new design? I'd argue no, it feels like an unnecessary abstraction. We can just implement sysfs support as a backend in the new LED controller EM reactor.

Done

Updated the diagram and all the abstraction will be done under phosphor-led-sysfs daemon.

A more conventional way of saying this is might be "Entity-manager exposes the LED configuration for a given board on DBus based on the board's configuration file"

From there, a part of what you need to do is to define an LED schema in EM if we don't already have one.

Part of the purpose of the "Alternatives Considered" section is to argue why they are _not as good_ as your proposed solution.

Your document needs to be an argumentative essay, as documented in this patch:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/commit/9db762d8848a51c4b68c8ba4385c541d806a447f

As mentioned in that patch, the Grammarly blog has an excellent breakdown of what this means:

https://www.grammarly.com/blog/argumentative-essay/

Scale wasn't a concern I had, more so that inotify is a strange way to do IPC when we already have a well-established IPC mechanism (DBus).

But again, you need to demonstrate why this is a worse solution than what you're proposing above.

I suspect you just tripled the work by trying to read the configuration from entity-manager ;) 

It has a requirement that it can't have any software specific information in it, such as names that have to match a device tree name.

You may want to include in this document what entity-manager information you'd have to use, so that ahead of time the EM maintainer can check if it's allowed.

It also seems to me like the EM support could all be phased in later if desired, as the D-Bus interfaces your daemon provides wouldn't have to change if the back end was changed.

Hi Andrew,

I have updated the design based on the entity-manager configurations for physical LEDs. Also submitted the implementation in gerrit (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/+/56590).

Could you please provide your suggestion on this.

Thanks
This largely looks how I'd expect now. Thanks for the write-up and apologies again for taking some time to review it. A couple of comments.

Hi Jayashree, Vernon has made a pretty fundamental observation that the document doesn't describe how you propose solving the problem you posed. For that I'd prefer this is not submitted as is and that you do some rework to address it.

I think the primary thing we're trying to solve is:

How do you associate multiple GPIOs, which each represent a color, into a single LED concept.

Our systems have an "amber and green" LED that has two wires coming out of it.  Currently we cannot represent this in the kernel directly via device tree.  The way virtual-leds is currently implemented it is difficult to represent "You may only have amber OR green on (but not both)" because that state might be spread across multiple virtual LEDs, so you end up having to create virtual-virtual LEDs... (this is a horrible explanation).

I haven't reviewed the document again lately but wanted to leave this comment so this primary need at an implementation level doesn't get lost in the higher level abstraction.

> so you end up having to create virtual-virtual LEDs... (this is a horrible explanation).

🤣

But yeah, I understand that. I think Jayashree even explains that reasonably well in the problem description, but we fall short of describing the solution 🙂

Certainly getting everything into a single process makes it less of a headache to think about.

I am not sure by reading the design below how it fixes this problem. I see that it reduces the number of services, which I believe is a good thing, but grouping the LEDs or helping with a multi-host platform is not clear below.

Yeah, reading over it again I think you're right. I was distracted by an outcome that I would like to see (all LED objects exposed by a single service rather than one per service).

Jayashree, I don't think what you've written goes far enough in explaining how your proposed design helps solve the problem you've described (controlling individual LEDs as a group).

Is it achieved by LED groups in phosphor-led-manager? Are we trying to put together a mechanism to expose a single 'virtual' LED composed of two physical LEDs and phosphor-led-manager is none-the-wiser?

A new schema will be implemented in phosphor-led-sysfs repo to handle the color control for a group of LEDs and activate one LED which must be Blink/ON and set the remaining LEDs in the OFF state.

Updated the information in the latest patchset.
Can you explain why this is a requirement and not an implementation detail?
Changed the design doc and updated.

This is always a bit of a edge case. Technically this should just be described in the EM board configuration for either the BMC or backplane or wherever the LEDs are and there's no need to describe it in the devicetree. However, if it is static configuration (which it sounds like it is if you're proposing to put it in the devicetree) then the devicetree is not an unreasonable spot for it. We just need to make sure that neither EM nor phosphor-led-sysfs detect when the LEDs already exist in sysfs and don't take any further action.
It seems to me that EM should only take action on entries listed in its config. If extra LEDs are described in the devicetree that are not in the EM config, they should just be ignored by EM.
The design doc is now changed to support udev event and entity-manager is not required now, since udev rule is used in existing platforms.

You'll need to add an LED schema to EntityManager for this. I don't think it's quite right that we use the type "SysfsLed". We should not bury Linux specifics in the device schema.

Let's ping the EM maintainers to get their thoughts.
The LED is exposed via sysfs from the description in the devicetree, isn't it? If that is the case, I don't see a problem with using SysfsLed as the type.

The question is, is the Type field meant to describe the interface or the implementation? Should it be the responsibility of the board configuration to dictate *how* the LED is controlled (sysfs vs e.g. raw GPIO)? I feel like that's an implementation detail. I feel like describing the type in this way means the EM configuration is dictating that the LED must also be described in the devicetree (as there's no way to create sysfs LEDs in userspace as far as I'm aware).

In the existing platforms, LEDs are configured via devicetree, therefore, udev support is proposed in the latest patchset. 

Entity manager can be used when plugable cards are present. Currently, EM support not required for this design, for that reason, it is removed.

We should probably describe what this interface is?

We will need both 'add' and 'remove'.  The systemd service for the udev event will need to handle udev add and udev remove.
I would prefer this to be an executable and not a shell.  It is still only a few lines of C++ code instead of a shellscript/busctl wrapper.
You'll need to make sure that the udev-triggered service is 'After'/'Wants' the primary service.
I'd like to see more details of how this integrates with system state and setting initial state of the LEDs.

1) This sounds like an implementation detail regarding initialization of the LED state.
2) Why must the LED be BLINK/ON?  Shouldn't the system state indicate whether a given LED should b ON/OFF/BLINK?  For instance, when the BMC is rebooted and the systems are not, the BMC discovers the systems are on and would need to read the existing GPIO state (or set the state based on the current system state).

This is the information detail for schema which needs to be implemented in phosphor-led-sysfs, whereas, phosphor-led-manager will handle the implementation for Power and System Identification LEDs based on the current system state. This schema will handle the color control for the specified system based on the result from phosphor-led-manager.

The UDEV Events, SERVICE and EXECUTABLE (DBUS Method Call) boxes should be outside the PHOSPHOR-LED-SYSFS DAEMON box, I think.

Otherwise, this is good.
This paragraph needs to be updated, the rest of the proposal doesn't talk about entity manager.
